title: A Falconer with Two Ladies and a Foot Soldier

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave.

artist_display: France or Flanders, possibly Paris or Bruges
description: Two fashionably dressed women, a man in falconer’s garb, another man in the less ornate costume of a foot soldier, and a dog occupy an island surrounded by a flat expanse covered in an overall pattern of small flowers and plants known as millefleur. The shallow, earthy cross section visible on the front edge of the island reveals that some attempt was made to create an impression of depth. It is unlikely that this image had any particular symbolic or narrative significance; rather, it was probably the decorative qualities of the figures’ stances and costumes and the fantastical millefleur setting that appealed to contemporary viewers. Such millefleur designs were extremely popular because of their accessibility, functional flexibility, and manageable scale. This particular example is of an appropriate size and subject to have hung in the home of a wealthy family.
medium_display: Wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave
publication_history:
Meyric R. Rogers and Oswald Goetz, Handbook to the Lucy Maud Buckingham Medieval Collection.  (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1945),73,  no. 63.

Christa Charlotte Mayer, Masterpieces of Western Textiles (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1969), 25, pl. 9.

Koenraad Brosens, ed., Christa C. Mayer Thurman, gen. ed., European Tapestries in the Art Institute of Chicago, exh. cat., [exhibition: "The Divine Art: Four Centuries of European Tapestries in the Art Institute of Chicago"] (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2008) 56-62, cat. 5.

Heinrich Gobel, Wandteppiche, II Teil, Band I. (Leipzig, 1928), 276 ff., Band II, pl. 311 (ill.).

Raimond Van Marle, Iconographie de l'art profane, La Vie Quotidienne (La Haye, 1931), 30. fig. 24 (ill.)..
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Masterpieces of Western Textiles, Jan. 25–Mar. 2, 1969.

Art Institute of Chicago, The Artist Looks at the Landscape, June 22–Sept. 1, 1974.

Art Institute of Chicago, Tapestries from the Permanent Collection, June 30–Sept. 30, 1979.

Moscow, Pushkin Museum, and Leningrad (now St. Petersberg), the Hermitage, Medieval Art from Late Antique through Late Gothic from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Art Institute of Chicago, 1990.

Art Institute of Chicago, Elizabeth F. Cheney and Agnes Allerton Textile Galleries, “Renaissance Velvets and Silks,” Dec. 18, 2002–Apr. 13, 2003.

Art Institute of Chicago, Regenstein Hall, The Divine Art: Four Centuries of European Tapestry, Nov. 1, 2008–Jan. 4, 2009.
provenance_text: An unidentified European family, to 1920; sold to Jacques Seligmann and Company, Paris, 1920; transferred to Jacques Seligmann and Company, New York, Nov. 3. 1920; sold to Kate S. Buckingham (died 1937), Chicago, April 6, 1922 [invoice, Apr. 6, 1922, no. 1457, copy in curatorial object file; on loan to the Art Institute of Chicago from May 20, 1922, incoming receipt R490, loan number 2499.22]; given to the Art Institute, 1922

input: A Falconer with Two Ladies and a Foot Soldier
